Propane dehydrogenation (PDH) is an attractive method for propylene production. PtxFe/ZSM-5 catalysts were prepared by the sequential incipient wetness impregnation of Fe and Pt on ZSM-5 support. The promoting effect of Fe on the catalytic performance of PtxFe/ZSM-5 during propane dehydrogenation reaction was studied. Various characterization techniques including N2 adsorption/desorption, ICP-OES, HRTEM, XPS, CO-DRIFT and TG were employed to unravel the properties of the catalysts. The experimental results confirmed the importance of Fe as a promotor in PDH. Suitable loading of Fe could obviously improve propane conversion, propylene selectivity, and the anti-coking ability of the catalysts, while excessive Fe caused metal aggregation and promoted side reactions, leading to a decreased propylene selectivity. When Fe loading was 1.0 %, the resulting Pt1.0Fe/ZSM-5 exhibited the best catalytic performance (propane conversion = 47.1 %, and propylene selectivity = 78.9 %), and it also showed good catalytic stability after regeneration. Pt0.5Fe/ZSM-5 showed the lowest coke amount of 0.10 gc·gcat −1, and the addition of 0.5 % Fe in Pt/ZSM-5 catalyst decreased 61.5 % of coke deposits. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Propane dehydrogenation Pt-based catalyst Fe promoter ZSM-5 Heterogeneous catalysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Propylene is one of the important building blocks for the production of a variety of chemicals, such as polypropylene, acrylonitrile, isopropanol, propylene oxide, etc. [1]. Propylene is traditionally obtained from steam cracking and fluid catalytic cracking (FCC) of naphtha and vacuum gas oil (VGO) [2,3]. However, due to the rapid consumption of crude oil, the supply of propylene from conventional processes cannot meet the growing global demand for the downstream products. Consequently, alternative processes for propylene production including propane dehydrogenation (PDH) [4], Fischer−Tropsch-to-olefins (FTO) [5], methanol-to-olefins (MTO) [6,7] have been developed and intensively studied. Among these technologies, propane dehydrogenation is recognized as the most promising method due to its high propylene selectivity and the abundance of propane in shale gas [4,8]. PDH is a typical highly endothermic reaction (Eq. (1)), which requires relatively high temperatures (550−700 °C [9]) to achieve a reasonable propane conversion. The conversion of propane can be raised by increasing the reaction temperature and reducing the partial pressure of propane reactant and H2 product [10]. However, the undesired CC cracking reaction of propane and coke formation on the catalyst are easily to occur at high temperatures, and side reactions of propylene with unsaturated carbon-carbon double bond (such as cracking, hydrogenolysis and isomerization) are difficult to avoid. Therefore, the exploration and design of efficient catalyst with high propylene selectivity and yield is of vital importance for propane dehydrogenation process. (1) C 3 H 8 → C 3 H 6 + H 2 , Δ H 298 K θ = 124 KJ mo l − 1 There are mainly two types of PDH catalysts, i.e., Pt- and Cr-based catalysts [4,11,12]. Compared to Cr-based catalysts, Pt-based catalysts possess the advantages of environmental friendliness, robust activity and excellent stability [13]. As a result, Pt-containing catalysts have been widely studied for PDH. The catalytic performance of the traditional supported catalysts in PDH is affected by the dispersion of Pt particles and coke deposition on the catalysts, which heavily depends on the acid-base properties of the support and the interactions between the metal and support. For Pt-based catalysts, coke deposits formed during PDH would encapsulate the active Pt sites, leading to a decrease of active catalytic sites. Additionally, the aggregation of active sites is beneficial for side reactions, which lower propylene selectivity. Therefore, enhancing Pt dispersion on the support and preventing Pt particle aggregation have attracted great attention, which are generally achieved by tuning the metal-support interactions and/or introducing promotors. Shi et al. prepared a Pt-Sn/Al2O3 catalyst by using a large amount of pentacoordinate Al3+ ions in Al2O3 nanosheet support to disperse and stabilize Pt-Sn clusters, which enhanced the interactions between the metal and support [14]. Consequently, the resulting Pt-Sn/Al2O3 sample displayed excellent activity for propylene production with >99 % selectivity and superior anti-coking and anti-sintering properties. Wang et al. found that 2.5 %Si@PtGa/Al2O3 with 0.1 wt.% active Pt sites exposed and stabilized in the Ga clusters of silica and alumina interlayer showed 90.7 % of propylene selectivity, although the initial propylene yield was only 18.5 % [9]. The proposed strategy provided strong metal-support interactions to anchor Pt particles and prevent isolated active Pt sites migrating, and thus gave a stable coordination environment to Pt catalyst during PDH process. Rimaz et al. [15]. confirmed that the promoting effect of Ge on Pt-based catalysts for PDH was ascribed to an alloy formation between Pt and Ge, and the addition of Ca in Pt-Ge/Al2O3 led to a decrease of acid centers of Al2O3 and an increase of the degree of Pt-Ge alloy formation, which enhanced propylene selectivity (98.5 % versus 96.4 % at 600 °C and 24 h TOS) and catalyst stability [16]. Besides Sn, Ga and Ge, other metal promotors (e.g., In [17], Cu [18], Fe [19], Mn [20] and Ce [21]) have also been investigated for enhancing PDH performance of Pt catalysts via modifying Pt ensembles or electronic effects. Qiu et al. found that Fe-promoted Pt/Sn-SBA-15 catalyst showed a maximum initial propane conversion of 56.8 % compared to others (i.e., Ce-, In- and La- promoted catalysts) [22]. Although Fe promotor exhibited great potential in propane dehydrogenation, its poor catalytic stability is one of the main problems, and it is still challenging to obtain a catalyst with high catalytic activity and good stability in the dehydrogenation of propane. ZSM-5 is an MFI type porous material with hierarchical structure which consists of two perpendicularly interconnecting channel systems [23]. The distinct porous feature can hamper the entrance of big molecules, further restrict the condensation and/or oligomerization reactions which are mostly related to the coke deposition. On the other hand, ZSM-5 itself is a solid acid and the acidic property can be tuned by changing the Si/Al ratio. Besides, it also shows extraordinary thermal stability even in the presence of steam. All of these makes it suitable for dispersing Pt as propane dehydrogenation catalyst. In this work, bimetallic PtxFe/ZSM-5 catalysts were prepared and evaluated for propane dehydrogenation. The porous structure of ZSM-5 was beneficial for the high dispersion of active metal sites and preventing their aggregation. The high Si/Al ratio of ZSM-5 led to relatively low acidity of catalysts, inhibiting side reactions to occur. Various characterization techniques were employed to study the properties of PtxFe/ZSM-5 catalysts, and their effects on the catalytic performance of PtxFe/ZSM-5 were also investigated. 2 Experimental The details of the experimental section including materials, catalyst preparation, characterization and catalytic propane dehydrogenation test were provided in the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Porosity Fig. 1 shows the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms and the pore size distributions of the different catalysts. No hysteresis loops were observed, and all catalysts showed type I isotherms according to the IUPAC classification, indicating the microporous nature. Similar N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms were obtained for Pt/ZSM-5 and binary PtxFe/ZSM-5 samples, implying that the microporous feature was not affected at current loading level, while the evident changes could be found from the pore size distribution. The pores of the catalysts were in a range of 1−5 nm, which revealed that both micropores and mesopores existed in ZSM-5 (i.e., hierarchical structure). Pt/ZSM-5 showed the largest specific surface area of 404.7 m2·g−1 and total pore volume of 0.25 cm3·g−1. It contained the pores with diameters of < 2 nm, 3−4 nm and 4−5 nm. As Fe was added and its loading increased, the specific surface area and total pore volume gradually decreased (as shown in Table 1 . The pore size distribution for Pt1.0Fe/ZSM-5 changed significantly, the zones including <2 nm and 3−4 nm shrank, and the ones like 2.1−2.4 nm and 2.4−3.4 nm were newly formed. When the loading of Fe species went higher, the zone <2 nm diminished and the other zones got weakening. These results suggested that pore blocking especially for the micropores happened during impregnation. ICP-OES measurements were performed to determine the actual Pt and Fe loadings, which were compared with the theoretical ones, as listed in Table 1. The actual Pt loadings were comparable to the theoretical ones (0.5 %). For Fe loading, there were slight mass loss during catalyst preparation since all actual loadings were smaller than the theoretical ones. 3.2 Crystalline phase Fig. 2 shows the PXRD patterns of the reduced PtxFe/ZSM-5 catalysts. There were strong peaks at around 2θ = 7.9°, 8.7°, 23.1°, 23.9° and 24.3°, which belonged to the characteristic peaks of MFI type zeolite. It indicated that metal impregnation did not change the crystalline phase of ZSM-5 support. All these samples showed obvious diffraction peaks at 2θ = 39.8°, 46.3° and 67.5°, corresponding to the (111), (200) and (220) planes of metallic Pt [24]. The PXRD results confirmed that Pt was successfully loaded on ZSM-5 support. The intensity of the characteristic peaks of Pt decreased with Fe loading, implying the addition of Fe was beneficial for Pt dispersion. No characteristic peaks belong to FeOx were observed on all samples. The peaks at 2θ = 44.6° and 65.0° were attributed to the (110) and (200) planes of metallic Fe. They only appeared on samples with relatively high Fe loadings, and their intensity increased with Fe loading. It was possibly because that when the Fe loading was high, Fe particles were easily to aggregate together to form larger particles, and to be detected by PXRD. In contrast, when Fe loading was low, Fe was highly dispersed on the support, which could not be detected. In addition, no peaks belong to PtFe alloy were observed on all samples, indicating no alloy was formed during catalyst preparation. 3.3 Morphology The morphology of the synthesized bimetallic PtFe catalysts was studied by HRTEM images, as shown in Fig. 3 . The interplanar distance of 0.226 nm was found on all samples, which corresponded to the (111) crystal plane of metallic Pt [25]. The findings were in consistent with the PXRD results. The interplanar distance of 0.210 nm belonged to the (111) crystal plane of metallic Fe, which was observed on Pt1.0Fe/ZSM-5 with a low Fe loading of 1.0 %. It confirmed the existence of Fe in the as-synthesized catalysts even when Fe loading was quite low. The particle size of Pt and Fe were calculated according to HRTEM images. As the amount of Fe increased in the catalyst, Pt particle size firstly increased and then decreased. As a result, the average Pt particle size increased in an order of Pt0.5Fe/ZSM-5 (3.8 nm) < Pt2.0Fe/ZSM-5 (3.9 nm) <Pt4.0Fe/ZSM-5 (4.0 nm) <Pt1.0Fe/ZSM-5 (4.2 nm). It suggested that suitable amount of Fe promotor could enhance Pt dispersion and inhibit Pt aggregation, while high loadings of Fe promotor would cause metal aggregation, which was not beneficial for the catalytic reaction. 3.4 Chemical state of the surface elements XPS measurements were carried out over the reduced samples to study the chemical state of the surface elements and their distribution. There were overlaps of the spectra of Al 2p and Pt 4f at 74.5−75.5 eV [26]. The XPS spectra of Pt 4f (including Pt 4f7/2 and Pt 4f5/2) is shown in Fig. 4 . There were three types of Pt species including metallic Pt (Pt0) at 71.0 eV and 73.9 eV, Pt2+ at 72.5 eV and 75.7 eV, and Pt4+ at 74.9 eV and 77.8 eV, suggesting that PtO2 were not fully reduced to metallic Pt. The peak at binding energy of 74.5 eV originated from Al2p spectrum, while the one at 76.6 eV was ill-defined, and it cannot be assigned to any Pt species that may exist in current catalysts. A variety of Fe species could be obtained after H2 reduction, including Fe2O3, Fe3O4, FeO and metallic Fe (Fe0) [27]. The Fe in Fe3O4 comprises two oxidation states, Fe2+ and Fe3+, the former octahedrally coordinated (i.e. Fe2+(oct)) and the latter distributed over both octahedral and tetrahedral sites (i.e., Fe3+(oct) and Fe3+(tet), respectively) [28]. Since there were overlaps between the spectra of Pt 4 s and Fe 2p1/2 at 725−726 eV [29,30], only the XPS spectra of Fe 2p3/2 was studied, as shown in Fig. 5 . Four different Fe species including Fe0 at 706.8 eV, Fe2+(oct) at 709.7 eV, Fe3+(oct) at 711.2 eV and Fe3+(tet) at 712.5 eV were found on the reduced catalysts. The satellite peaks of Fe2+ and Fe3+ were located at around 714.6 eV and 717.8 eV, respectively. Therefore, only part of Fe species was reduced to metallic Fe, and both Fe2+ and Fe3+ existed in the ZSM-5 support after H2 reduction, which was in good agreement with the research findings from the literature [31–33]. The quantification results of XPS spectra are summarized in Table 2 . Pt was mainly existed as Pt0 in Pt/ZSM-5 sample (72.4 %). After loading 0.5 wt.% Fe on the catalyst Pt0.5Fe/ZSM-5, the content of Pt0 decreased from 72.4 % to 52.8 %, while the amount of Pt2+ and Pt4+ increased from 13.9 % to 25.3 %, and from 13.7 % to 21.9 %, respectively. As Fe loading continuously increased, the surface content of Pt0 decreased gradually to 34.3 %, and that of Pt2+gradually increased to 45.6 % for Pt4.0Fe/ZSM-5. The existence of FeOx was averse to the reduction of Pt. The formation of PtO was favorable on the catalysts with high Fe loadings [34,35], and high Fe loadings could enhance the formation of PtO2. The majority of Pt species changed from Pt0 to Pt2+ and Pt4+ when the loading of Fe was higher than 0.5 wt.%, suggesting that the reduction of Pt oxide became more difficult as a consequence of enhanced interactions between the metal and the support. In the meantime, the content of Fe0 continuously increased from 0 to 16.6 %. Regardless of Fe loadings, the percentage of Fe2+(oct) in the catalysts maintained at 33.4 %−34.1 %. As for Fe3+, the amount of Fe3+(oct) gradually decreased from 39.0 % to 27.9 %, while Fe3+(tet) content slightly fluctuated in a range of 21.3 %−27.3 %. It demonstrated that the reduction process of Fe3O4→ FeO→ Fe0 was enhanced with an increasing Fe loading. The changes in the atomic ratio of Pt and Fe species under the same reduction conditions were attributed to the different interactions between Pt and Fe due to various Fe loadings on the catalysts. Hydrogen spillover from Pt0 sites to Fe0 sites might happen in the bimetallic PtxFe/ZSM-5 catalysts [36], and then hydrogen further transferred to the adjacent FeOx for its reduction [37,38]. The element composition of the catalyst surface was also listed in Table 2. The surface mass ratio of Pt on Pt/ZSM-5 was 0.1 wt.%, which increased to 0.19 wt.% after adding 0.5 % of Fe. With a further increase in Fe loading, the surface mass ratio of Pt gradually decreased to 0.11 wt.% on Pt4.0Fe/ZSM-5, possibly resulted from Pt aggregation. High loadings of Fe were not good for Pt dispersion on catalyst surface due to the strong Pt-Fe interactions. Moreover, all Fe-containing samples had a similar surface mass ratio of Fe (around 0.30 wt.%). 3.5 DRIFT study of adsorbed CO DRIFT spectra of adsorbed CO have been proven to be an effective tool to study the local electronic environment of the bimetallic particles. In this work, it was employed to investigate the effect of Fe promotor on the active Pt sites. The CO adsorption bands on the bimetallic catalysts with various Fe loadings are presented in Fig. 6 . Generally, the peak area of the linear adsorption of CO was inversely proportional to the Pt nanoparticle size since smaller Pt nanoparticles tend to be adsorbed by more CO molecules [39]. The band at around 1821 cm−1 was assigned to the bridge CO adsorption on the adjacent Pt-Pt sites, and the band at 1935 cm−1 was assigned to CO adsorption on Fe0 [40], confirming that the Fe oxides were partially reduced. The two overlap bands located at 2097 cm−1 and 2120 cm−1 were due to the linear adsorption of CO, and the former was mainly caused by the linear CO adsorption on Pt0 site with high dispersion. On the contrary, the shoulder at around 2076 cm−1, ascribed to linearly adsorbed CO on Pt0 with bigger particle size due to agglomeration [15], was rather weak even invisible, which suggested that the Pt sites were well isolated by Fe species. The band at 2120 cm−1 was ascribed to the adsorption of polycarbonyl on Pt2+ species. In addition, the band appeared at 2169 cm−1 was assigned to CO adsorption on Ptδ+(Ptδ+-CO) with higher oxidative state (δ>2) [41,42]. It should be noted that the intensity of bridge CO adsorption band at 1821 cm−1 first increased and then decreased as Fe content increased, suggesting suitable amount of Fe promotor could promote Pt dispersion and inhibit its aggregation. The findings were in consistence with the results from HRTEM images. 3.6 Acidity by NH3-TPD and pyridine probe FT-IR NH3-TPD was performed to determine the amount of acidic site and the strength distribution, and the desorption curves were gathered in Fig. 7 (A). All the samples showed similar NH3 desorption behavior. The desorption below 235 °C was assigned to the weak adsorption of ammonia on catalyst surface which was defined as weak acid site. Another desorption process took place between 235 and 450 °C, suggesting stronger interaction between ammonia and catalyst surface which was defined as medium acid site. The strong acid sites, corresponding to the desorption at higher than 450 °C, were absent in the catalysts as no evident peak was observed. The quantified results in Table 3 revealed that the number of weak acid site were comparable (ca. 0.21 mmol/g), while that of medium acid site slightly increased from 0.06 mmol/g for Pt0.5Fe/ZSM-5 to 0.11 mmol/g for Pt4Fe/ZSM-5. The type of acidic site was identified by in situ pyridine adsorbed FT-IR measurement because the Brönsted (B) and Lewis (L) acid can interact with the probe molecule, and the resulting vibration of pyridine ring could be captured by infrared spectroscopy. Normally, the bands at ca. 1600 cm−1 and 1450 cm−1 originate from the adsorption of pyridine on Lewis acid site, the band at ca. 1545 cm−1 is from Brönsted acid site supplied by the surface acid hydroxyl groups, and the one at ca. 1490 cm−1 reflects the adsorption on both Brönsted and Lewis acid sites. It could be found from Fig. 7(B) that the Fe free sample Pt/ZSM-5 contained both B and L acid sites which were remained as different amount of Fe was introduced. It suggested that the addition of Fe did not influence the types of surface acid but the number of each. The Fe contained samples except Pt4.0Fe/ZSM-5 involved higher amount of B sites and comparable amount of L sites (ca. 0.05 mmol/g) when the content of Fe changed. As a result, the B/L ratio was higher than 1.0, implying that the presence of Fe species mainly promoted the formation of Brönsted acid. 3.7 Catalytic performance Fig. 8 shows the catalytic performance of the different catalysts with various Fe loadings in propane dehydrogenation at 580 °C for 8 h, and the results (including the initial conversion X 0, the final conversion X f, the average conversion X a and the product selectivity) are summarized in Table 4 . The addition of Fe significantly improved the performance of PDH. When Fe content increased from 0 for monometallic Pt/ZSM-5 to 4.0 wt.% for Pt4.0Fe/ZSM-5, the initial conversion of propane continuously increased from 25.7 % to 65.7 % which was not far from the theoretic equilibrium conversion of 65.9 % [43]. However, large amounts of metal loading caused serious aggregation of active sites, and thus led to catalyst deactivation. Consequently, the final conversions of propane on all catalysts were obviously lower than the initial values. Pt1.0Fe/ZSM-5 exhibited the best finial conversion of propane after 8 h (44.2 %) and a maximum average conversion of propane (47.1 %). As seen from the product distribution, cracking reactions happened over Pt/ZSM-5 catalyst because CH4 and C2H4 were produced during PDH reaction. Nevertheless, the average propylene selectivity over Pt/ZSM-5 reached 62.1 %. Similar product distribution was also obtained on 1.0Fe/ZSM-5 but with a quite low conversion of propane (3.5 %), suggesting that the mono Fe species were less active for propane dehydrogenation, and the acidic site might play a dominant role in determining the catalytic performance. After loading Fe promotor, similar product distribution over PtxFe/ZSM-5 catalysts indicated that the addition of Fe did not change the reaction pathways of PDH, while the selectivity of propylene obviously increased compared to Pt/ZSM-5 due to the limitation of side reactions. The average selectivity towards propylene during a reaction duration of 8 h firstly increased with Fe loadings, and then decreased. It was because that suitable loading of Fe could enhance Pt dispersion and then PDH reaction, but excessive Fe content might cause active site aggregation and then deactivation. The best propylene selectivity (78.9 %) was also obtained when Pt1.0Fe/ZSM-5 was used as PDH catalyst. When comparing the current results with the reported ones in Table 5, it could be found that the propylene selectivity kept at a relatively low level. Considerable amount of ethylene was detected in the products, suggesting that the cracking reaction was enhanced, which was probably related to the presence of Brönsted acid in the catalyst (cf. Fig. 7) [44]. The catalytic stability test of Pt1.0Fe/ZSM-5 for PDH in 30 h time on stream (TOS) is shown in Fig. 9 . The initial conversion of propane was 49.9 % which declined to 42.3 % within 8 h TOS, with an average value of 46.2 %. These reaction data were quite close to those in Table 4, indicating that the catalyst exhibited good reproductivity. The catalyst underwent a continuous deactivation to 13.5 % till the end with 30 h time on stream, while propylene selectivity fluctuated at approximately 78 %. Although the activity of Pt1.0Fe/ZSM-5 catalyst decreased during reaction, it always showed a decent selectivity towards propylene over a reaction duration of 30 h. Fig. 10 shows the cyclic test of PDH over Pt1.0Fe/ZSM-5 catalyst. After each reaction for 8 h, the spent catalyst was calcined in air at 600 °C, and then reduced in a mixture of H2/N2 for regeneration. In the first cycle, propane conversion decreased from 49.6 % to 44.5 %. After the first-time regeneration, it decreased from 66.2 % to 52.0 % in the second cycle. After the second-time regeneration, the conversion of propane increased to 69.2 %, which decreased to 57.5 % after 8 h. For propylene selectivity, the values in the second cycle were slightly higher than those in the first cycle, while propylene selectivity in the second cycle was comparable to those in the third cycle. The results indicated that the catalytic activity of Pt1.0Fe/ZSM-5 catalyst improved after each regeneration. It was possibly because that Pt and Fe redispersed on the support after reaction-oxidation–reduction, and more active sites were exposed after regeneration, leading to enhanced propane conversion and propylene selectivity. Furthermore, a kinetic study was carried out to get a deep understanding on the effects of Fe loading on the catalytic performance in PDH. Fig. 11 shows the consumption rate of propane (r propane) and the apparent activation energy of PDH (E a) in the presence of different catalysts. The turnover frequency (TOF), propane consumption rate, the apparent activation energy and the deactivation constant (k d) were calculated according to the obtained plots and on the basis of actual Pt loading (as listed in Table 6 ). Propane consumption rate and the TOF showed the same trend with Fe loading, i.e., decreased first and then increased. Their values on the bimetallic catalysts were higher than those on the monometallic Pt/ZSM-5 catalyst, except Pt0.5Fe/ZSM-5, which had the lowest TOF of 0.054 s−1 and propane consumption rate of 1.1 mmol·gPt −1·s−1. For the bimetallic PtxFe/ZSM-5 catalyst, the trends of the calculated TOF and propane consumption rate were in good agreement with that of the initial propane conversion in Table 4, i.e., increasing with Fe loading in the catalysts. The apparent activation energy of PDH was calculated at a propane conversion of <10 % achieved by changing catalyst mass and reaction temperature. E a exhibited a reverse trend compared to propane consumption rate and the TOF. It firstly increased and then decreased, and the largest value of E a (142.7 kJ·mol−1) was achieved over Pt0.5Fe/ZSM-5 catalyst. Similarly, except Pt0.5Fe/ZSM-5, the use of other bimetallic PtFe catalysts could reduce the apparent activation energy of the reaction. However, the introduction of Fe promotor resulted in improved deactivation constants due to the metal aggregation. 3.8 Characterization of the spent catalyst Fig. 12 shows the PXRD patterns of the spent catalysts after 8 h of PDH reaction. The diffraction peaks of metallic Pt and Fe still remained after reaction, meaning that the crystalline phases of the catalysts did not change. Compare to the PXRD patterns of fresh catalysts in Fig. 2, the intensity of the diffraction peaks of metallic Pt at 2θ = 39.8° and 46.3° and metallic Fe at 2θ = 44.6° decreased, which was possibly due to the coke deposits on the spent catalyst, which covered part of the active metal sites. On the spent catalysts, the characteristic diffraction peaks of both Pt3O4 and PtFe alloy were observed, suggesting some Pt species were transformed into Pt3O4 and PtFe alloy during PDH reaction. Coke deposition is one of the main reasons for catalyst deactivation. The coke deposits on the spent catalysts were determined by TG tests in air atmosphere, as shown in Fig. 13 . A continuous weight loss was observed for all spent catalysts until ∼700 °C. The first weight loss taking place below 450 °C was attribute to the removal of water, while the second weight loss in a temperature range of 450−700 °C was due to the combustion of coke on the spent catalysts. The quantitative results of the coke amount on the spent catalysts are summarized in Table 7 . The coke content increased in an order of Pt0.5Fe/ZSM-5 < Pt/ZSM-5 < Pt1.0Fe/ZSM-5 < Pt2.0Fe/ZSM-5 < Pt4.0Fe/ZSM-5. The highest coke content of 0.47 gc/gcat was found on Pt4.0Fe/ZSM-5, while Pt0.5Fe/ZSM-5 showed the lowest coke amount of 0.10 gc/gcat. Compared to Pt/ZSM-5 (0.26 gc/gcat), the addition of 0.5 % Fe in the catalyst decreased 61.5 % of coke deposits, but a further increase of Fe loading resulted in more coke formation during PDH process. 4 Conclusions PtxFe/ZSM-5 catalysts were prepared by the sequential incipient wetness impregnation of Fe and Pt on ZSM-5 support. The experimental results confirmed the promoting effect of Fe on Pt/ZSM-5 catalysts for PDH because both propane conversion and propylene selectivity over bimetallic PtFe catalysts were higher than those on monometallic Pt/ZSM-5 catalyst. The addition of suitable amount of Fe as catalyst promotor could promote the catalytic performance in propane dehydrogenation, but excessive Fe loading would decrease Pt dispersion and thus catalytic activity. Among all catalysts with various Fe loadings, Pt1.0Fe/ZSM-5 sample exhibited the best performance with an average propane conversion of 47.1 % and a mean propylene selectivity of 78.9 % under the experimental conditions used. Pt0.5Fe/ZSM-5 showed the lowest coke amount of 0.10 gc·gcat −1, and the addition of 0.5 % Fe in Pt/ZSM-5 catalyst decreased 61.5 % of coke deposits. For the catalysts with high Fe loadings, large amounts of coke deposits were formed during PDH reaction, which was not beneficial for metal dispersion on the support, promoting side reactions. It demonstrated that a desired PDH catalyst with good activity and stability should have a relatively low Fe0 content and high amounts of Fe2+ and Ptδ+. coredata.dc:description: Propane dehydrogenation (PDH) is an attractive method for propylene production. PtxFe/ZSM-5 catalysts were prepared by the sequential incipient wetness impregnation of Fe and Pt on ZSM-5 support. The promoting effect of Fe on the catalytic performance of PtxFe/ZSM-5 during propane dehydrogenation reaction was studied. Various characterization techniques including N2 adsorption/desorption, ICP-OES, HRTEM, XPS, CO-DRIFT and TG were employed to unravel the properties of the catalysts. The experimental results confirmed the importance of Fe as a promotor in PDH. Suitable loading of Fe could obviously improve propane conversion, propylene selectivity, and the anti-coking ability of the catalysts, while excessive Fe caused metal aggregation and promoted side reactions, leading to a decreased propylene selectivity. When Fe loading was 1.0 %, the resulting Pt1.0Fe/ZSM-5 exhibited the best catalytic performance (propane conversion = 47.1 %, and propylene selectivity = 78.9 %), and it also showed good catalytic stability after regeneration. Pt0.5Fe/ZSM-5 showed the lowest coke amount of 0.10 gc·gcat −1, and the addition of 0.5 % Fe in Pt/ZSM-5 catalyst decreased 61.5 % of coke deposits.
